Here's a cute math puzzler I heard recently.
 
 Must it be the case that there exists two antipodal spots on the equator that have the same temperature?
 
 Why or why not?

It turns out that mathematically you can prove this is true.
 
 That is, if you define a function F(a,b)=Ta-Tb where Ta is the temperature at any given point and Tb is the temperature at its antipodal point on the equator.
 
 Since the temperature Ta is continuous with respect to da and Tb is continuous with respect to db, then F is also continuous.
 
 Assuming that not all points on the equator have the same temperature, there must exist, reasonably some point for a and b for which Ta<Tb and F is positive. There must also exist some point for which Tb<Ta and F is negative. Since F is a continuous function and since it has some negative values and some positive values, it must be true that there is some (a,b) for which F is zero.
 
 Therefore 0=Ta-Tb and Ta=Tb.
 
 :)

 No, it is not necessary that there exist two antipodal spots on the equator that have identical temperatures in reality. The Borsuk-Ulam theorem applies to a conceptual mathematical construct, and can be used to "model" reality, but it no way does it necessitate existence of any kind. (perhaps we believe that god's existence can be shown mathematically???)
 
 Realistically, there are not an infinite number of points along the equator. The functions of both position around a planetary body and temperature at any such position cannot be shown to be "continuous". 
 
 There is no "must exist" when dealing with conceptual mathematical representations with such obvious built-in inaccuracies. May exist, perhaps but then we'd have to calculate probability given the accuracy of the measurements (both position and temperature).
 
 Mathematically this is an exercise in infinite probability which allows for a quick and fairly accurate answer to what is a model (with inaccuracies) of a real world problem.
 
 The math used to answer your question assumes that between any two points there are an infinite number of points and that this infinite number of points is continuous (!). That is, if two points had a measurement of 90deg and 100 deg., it is a requirement that there exist a point between the two points that is (exactly!) 91degrees...which is not realistic. Yes, given an infinite probability, all possibilities are infinitely present, which is IMO the general form of the puzzle. Given an infinite number of points and a possibility of each point being a particular temperature on a continuous scale, if it's possible that two points have identical temperatures then there exist an infinite number of such antipodal pairs with identical temperatures. So the puzzle is somewhat misleading in that it hides it's infinity in a single pair.
 
 Must it be the case that there exists AN INFINITE NUMBER OF PAIRS OF antipodal spots on the equator that have the same temperature? No, but in a mathematical model that is probably a close representation of reality, sure.
 
 A gross simplication of a similar real-world problem would be given an infinite number of chances for there to exist a human, if it's possible for that human to be Mach, then an infinite number of Mach's exist. I think Bruno was burned to death for claiming that ;)
